translated: The Buddha Speaks the SÅ«tra on the Mind of Abuse
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master An Shigao of Arsakes in the Later Han Dynasty
The Buddha speaks of the mind of abuse. All the insects and ants in the ten directions have eaten me, and all the insects and ants in the ten directions
Have also eaten me - why do you not feel shame?
All the insects and ants in the ten directions are my wives, and I also take all the insects and ants in the ten directions as my wives - why can you not feel shame?
Having been in birth and death for a long time, beyond counting, you should cultivate the path, and should not cultivate the karma of being an animal.
There are five offenses in committing sexual misconduct:
First, losing money and wealth;
Second, falling into fear;
Third, fearing the county government;
Fourth, incurring resentment and disaster;
Fifth, upon the exhaustion of one's life, falling into the evil hells.
People obtain their bodies from form, food, and drink. As a human, there is nothing to fear, but only fear of becoming an animal, and entering the hells and the realm of hungry ghosts!
The practitioner shaves their beard and hair, begs for food, endures hunger and thirst;
Leaves home, abandons property;
The eyes do not look falsely, guarding the six sense faculties;
Avoiding evil conditions, wishing to escape suffering.

Moreover, giving rise to a single thought has a hundred kalpas of misfortune, like planting grain with a hundredfold or myriadfold return. Grain has no awareness, yet one always obtains a myriadfold return.
Human thoughts have awareness, so the fear is not just that!
When a person sits in meditation, if they see sea creatures or any objects, they are all creatures and objects from the water in past lives.

If they are birds or beasts, they have been birds and beasts in past lives. In this life, they obtain conditions, so their sins should only increase. What they see are all sins. They should be aware that in past lives, they were together in the hells.
Past sins are afflictions, present ones are sins that have yet to become misfortunes.
Evil has parents:
Ignorance is the evil father, craving is the evil mother.
Goodness also has parents:
The Sutra of Thirty-Seven Chapters is the good father, and the Six Perfections are the good mother.
There are also parents:
The Buddha is the father, and the Dharma is the mother.
Following the Buddha's words and practicing according to the Dharma is the practice of parents.
When a person falls into hell, a ghost wants to hold a stick and strike him.
The person's mind then thinks:
The ghost will eventually be destroyed and will not last long!
Thinking like this, he is then liberated and reborn in the heavens.
There are six things that lead to decline:
First, not serving the Buddha;
Second, not serving the Dharma;
Third, not serving the monastic community of precept-keeping monks;
Fourth, not serving the wise;
Fifth, not teaching many people to diligently practice the Way;
Sixth, discussing with the virtuous.
These six things lead to the increase of the Dharma.
One should not create offenses within blessings, but rather create blessings within offenses.
If a person is in a place of learning but does not practice the Way or recite the sutras, this is creating offenses within blessings.
If a person is sick and weak, or has troubles with the government, water, fire, or loss of wealth, but does not worry, this is creating blessings within offenses.

One should not create offenses within blessings, such as burning incense, scattering flowers, riding in a carriage, scolding, or acting in this way, waiting for this, this is creating offenses within blessings.
There are nine levels of killing, with varying degrees of offenses.
It is better to kill a thousand ants than to kill a single fly.
In this way, up to killing a human, the offense and retribution increase greatly.
Building a hundred Buddha temples is not as good as saving a single person.
Saving the people of the ten directions is not as good as guarding the mind for a single day.
If a person obtains a good mind, its blessings are immeasurable.
Giving to evil people will later lead to karmic relations with evil people, which is suffering.
Giving to good people is the accumulation of blessings.

Also, one should not accept evil people's things, and later meet with them, this is called being troubled by trouble.ğŸ”½It is better to accept good people's things and give to good people, one should not accept evil people's things and give to evil people.
It is better to give to evil people, not to accept good people's things;
It is better to accept good people's things, not to accept evil people's things.
One should cut off evil intentions when obtained, and also cut off good intentions when obtained.
Evil intentions lead to hell, animal realms, and hungry ghost realms;
Good intentions lead to the heavens and among humans - all should be cut off.
There are five demons that disturb people's minds, causing them not to attain the Way:
First, the heavenly demon;
Second, the demon of offenses;
Third, the demon of practice;
Fourth, the demon of afflictions;
Fifth, the demon of death.
Practitioners of the Way should be aware of these five demons when practicing the Way.
There are five things that the Buddhas of the ten directions cannot control:
First, one will forget one's past lives;
Second, one's life should ascend to the upper realms;
Third, one's life will be destroyed;
Fourth, one's life will grow old;
Fifth, one's life will die.
There is nothing that can prevent these things.
There are four things for a person in life:
First, there are those who plan good and good follows them;
Second, there are those who plan evil and evil follows them;
Third, there are those who plan good and evil follows them;
Fourth, there are those who plan evil and good follows them.
Whatever one thinks, the mind also perishes, the body also perishes, and the seen causes and conditions also perish.

As for the one who practices in the next world and receives blessings and misfortunes, it is like planting fruit. This year it has ripened and fallen to the ground, and next year there will be fruit again.
Sin is like a tree, and the causes and conditions of the mind are like the fruit.
There are four spirits who know the good and evil that a person does:
First, the earth spirit knows it;
Second, the heavenly spirit knows it;
Third, the bystander knows it;
Fourth, one should know it oneself.
There are three causes and conditions for the firm path:
First, practice;
Second, acceptance;
Third, calamity.
Committing evil deeds is called practice;
Having already arisen, it is called acceptance;
Having already accepted, it is calamity.

There were five sons of butchers who, when returning home in the evening, contemplated the Way. Later, their lives ended and they fell into evil paths. In the evening, they were delighted with the five pleasures until dawn, and then they were punished with the five tortures.
There are two kinds of people who accept the Buddha's words, namely the wise and the foolish, these are the two kinds.
Three things cannot be seen, just like precepts, various evils cannot be seen.
After the practitioner has transmitted the sutra, there are four kinds of blessings in practicing the Way:
First, practicing the Way single-mindedly, without eating or drinking, one can receive people's worship;
Second, being originally poor and having nothing, one can receive people's worship;
Third, if one has enough of one's own, one should not accept others' offerings;
Fourth, when practicing the Way with a human body, one should eat just enough and not accept too much.
One should accept the teachings in the sutras, not reject them. Hearing the sutras is also like this.
Even if one's explanation of the sutras confuses people's minds, there is no fault.
Why is it so?

When originally explaining the sutras, one does not wish to confuse people's minds. Although explaining the sutras may confuse people's minds, it is like eating poison and being about to die, but then taking an antidote to stop the poison, and thus not dying. The Buddha's sutras are like the antidote.
There are four things that fire cannot burn and weapons cannot harm an ascetic:
First, what the Buddha has not yet accepted;
Second, attaining cessation;
Third, attaining the four dhyanas;
Fourth, having the intention of the Way, not the intention of birth and death.

When the Buddha was in the world, he went to people's homes, and the hosts would close the doors, not wanting others to see the Buddha. Later in the world, people became blind. Therefore, the Buddha's sutras want to reveal.
Lighting lamps can attain the heavenly eye, and can also see from afar and have brightness;ğŸ”½Making wicks can attain good eye sockets;
Offering sesame oil can attain good pupils;
Offering fire can attain discernment.
From these causes and conditions, one can attain good eyes and lamps, and in the next life, one can attain gold, silver, and precious vessels.
When people speak evil things, confusing people's minds, this is the work of Mara, which should be recognized;
This is called a good person getting evil parents, which is a fault.
When Mara comes to scold, there is only wind, and the ears should avoid it, this is evil wind;
Not avoiding it, one is instead hit by the evil person's wind.
From these five, one attains sitting, and these five actions fall into the evil paths.
Entering a gathering of many people, there are four kinds of things that should be pulled out:
First, if one speaks contrary to the Dharma, confusing people's minds, one is then dragged out;
Second, if one sees that what is said is wrong but does not restrain it, one is dragged out;

Third, if one sees that what is done is not right but does not teach it, one is dragged out; Fourth, if one's questions are not in accordance with the Dharma and one does not speak again, one is dragged out.
In a gathering, near a gathering of practitioners, lice, fleas, insects, and ants bite people for four reasons:
First, one should receive punishment from past lives;
Second, demons come to destroy people, not wanting them to attain the Way;
Third, one does not seek a pure place;
Fourth, one's mind is not impartial.
There are eight kinds of people who cannot be trusted:
First, greedy people;
Second, jealous people;
Third, angry people;
Fourth, arrogant people;
Fifth, officials;
Sixth, people with different intentions;
Seventh, people with grudges;
Eighth, women, county officials, water, fire, snakes, and sharp knives are not to be approached, for approaching them can kill people.
There are five types of people who should not be given the sutra:
First, those who want others to know that they have the sutra, desiring to be self-important and gain fame;
Second, those who want to memorize the sutra but do not understand it themselves;
Third, those who want to receive offerings from others based on the sutra;
Fourth, those who want everyone to receive the sutra from them and make them their teacher;
Fifth, those who seek the sutra in order to escape birth and death and attain liberation from the cycle of existence, and can be given the sutra.
There are five types of people who should be given the sutra:
First, those who wish to hear the sutra many times;
Second, those who wish to perform many meritorious deeds;
Third, those who wish to understand the sutra;
Fourth, those who explain the sutra to others;
Fifth, those who wish to end birth and death.
There are five types of jealousy:
First, it is like when a person serves a teacher, wanting the teacher to love only them and not wanting the teacher to love others, this is called jealousy in residence;
Second, thinking to oneself, I am only a person, born in a small family, this is called jealousy in birth;
Third, seeing others being wealthy, wishing to be equal to them, this is called jealousy in wealth;
Fourth, having a deep sutra of the Buddha, wanting to obtain it alone and not wanting others to obtain it, this is called jealousy in sutras;
Fifth, seeing others being upright, thinking to oneself, I am not like that, this is called jealousy in appearance.
Offending these five jealousies, one cannot attain the Way.
A practitioner should not fall into the five disputes:
First, disputing the Buddha;
Second, disputing the Dharma;
Third, disputing the precepts;
Fourth, disputing the sutras;
Fifth, disputing the sages.
A practitioner should not dispute whether something exists or does not exist.
There are five kinds of firm errors:
First, errors of the body;
Second, firm in error;
Third, firm in wrong error;
Fourth, firm in greedy error;
Fifth, firm in admonitory error.
There are seven kinds of lust:
First, seeing the color of clothes;
Second, hearing the sound of a pearl ring;
Third, hearing the voice of a woman;
Fourth, thinking of talking about a woman in the mind;
Fifth, looking with the eyes;
Sixth, thinking of the etiquette of husband and wife;
Seventh, committing by mental conception.
These seven kinds of lust cannot attain the Way.
There are five causes for a person's fondness for forgetting:
First, forgetting the body;
Second, forgetting due to many thoughts;
Third, attachment to love;
Fourth, attachment to seeing;
Fifth, from past lives, meaning disturbing and frightening people in the past.
Forgetting due to fatigue means thinking with a tired mind.
Drinking alcohol leads to poison, drinking water leads to heavenly conditions, sleeping leads to death, speaking good words leads to heaven, speaking evil leads to hell - four parts are hell.
The king had a wife whose brother was about to enter hell. The wife said to the king:
Don't let my brother enter this hell!
The king said:
You stop him for me.
As the brother was about to enter, the wife said:
The gate to this hell is unapproachable!
The brother said:
There are many things in here.
He then ran into the hell.
People are pulled by their crimes like this.
There was a person who took another person's plow and yoke without permission, and when the plow was about to be returned,
the Buddha said:
You should not, it has already been stolen!
The person said:
I want to make a golden yoke to repay it.
The Buddha said:
The theft is not understood.
Upholding the precepts is filial piety, repaying the kindness of one's parents.
Why is it so?

By not killing living beings, one attains longevity; by not stealing, one becomes wealthy; by not engaging in sexual misconduct, chaos is avoided, and all become trustworthy; by not drinking alcohol, all become pure. If parents fall into these, they will be at ease.
When fasting in a Buddhist temple, one should not sleep on a monk's rope bed, bench, chair, or under the covers, as this is against the precepts.
If a layperson invites a monk, and the monk has not yet eaten, he should not ask about the sutras;
if the monk explains, there is an offense.
Only after the monk has eaten can he ask about the sutras and the Way.
Not upholding the precepts and not practicing the Way, dwelling in a Buddhist temple is no different than throwing oneself into a cauldron, as the cauldron only burns one body.
Not upholding the precepts and not practicing the Way, being in a Buddhist temple burns countless bodies.
Monks should also explain the sutras. If someone asks about the sutras, there should be no disagreement.
If someone offers things to a monk, one should not ask about the sutras, but can ask later.
When receiving things, one should not speak the sutras, as there is an offense.
There are five reasons why a monk should not accept an invitation:ğŸ”½First, if the invitation is not as good as another, one should not go;
Second, if the invitation is not as good as the previous one, one should not go;
Third, if invited to go to place A, but told to invite someone else to place B, one should not go;
Fourth, if invited from a distant place, but not immediately, and later invited, one should not go;
Fifth, if with an enemy or someone who is not harmonious, one should not go.
If sitting in the assembly, one should not go.
Why is it so?
Because one is sleeping and using the mind to stop.
There are three levels of stopping:
First, the practice of stopping birth and death;
Second, the mind of the path not reaching, stopping the mind due to the conditions of birth and death.
Moreover, a person who likes to sleep has three causes:
First, eating too much;
Second, drinking;
Third, worry.
There are also three causes:
First, resting the body;
Second, the remaining mind is extremely exhausted, and after lying down, it receives another mind;
Third, it is retained.
When a person lies down, there is intention, consciousness, life, breath, and respiration. During the day, there are 36,000 breaths, which are just small completeness, etc.
There are eight practices to eliminate sleepiness:
First, eating little;
Second, sitting;
Third, standing;
Fourth, walking;
Fifth, reciting scriptures;
Sixth, gazing at the stars;
Seventh, washing the face;
Eighth, contemplating the bones.
If one does not understand, one should think of good things. When the mind has turned, one should return to oneself.
In order to attain blessings, the Way, and concentration, one can understand by oneself after attaining mindfulness of other matters.
There are blessings attained by the body, blessings attained by speech and mind, and empty blessings;
there are also offenses committed by the body, offenses committed by speech and mind, and empty offenses.
Empty blessings refer to dreaming of obtaining gold, silver, precious treasures, nobility, and wealth and happiness. This is called empty blessings.
Empty offenses refer to dreaming of people coming to kill oneself or harming others. This is called empty offenses.
Speaking to others to do evil, or encouraging others to kill, later due to conditions one is unjustly beaten by others. This is called the offense of speech and mind.
Creating karma oneself as the cause and condition, being injured or killed by others, this is the offense of the mind.
The reason why people have good or bad dreams is because they want to eat and drink, but have no possessions, only thoughts. Due to this, they dream of delicious food and drink.
The mind wants to kill others, and due to this, one dreams of people coming to kill oneself.
All have causes and conditions, either from past or future lives or from the present life.
Dreams in the early night are about events of the morning and evening.
The good and evil in dreams are all created by the mind, and what one encounters is also entirely mental.
It is like a person who takes a single object, observes it, and then puts it away.
Although it is not seen, the mind thinks of it, and it comes, no different from what is seen.
What was done in a past life then naturally interacts with the mind in this life.
After a person dies, they sit up again because when they were alive they enjoyed scaring people with ghosts;
or when someone in the world becomes ill, they call out to those around them, saying they are awake.
For this reason, the dead sit up again.
There are four causes for falling into the dragon realm:
First, giving a lot;
Second, being very angry;
Third, looking down on others;
Fourth, sitting with self-importance.
These four things make one a dragon.
The first one gains blessings, and the latter three gain the body of a dragon.
The Vinaya Sutra says:
Those animals with horns are because in a past life they liked to wear horns, crossing them for beauty, and obtained the sin of horns, the body of an animal.
Some have different colors because they wore colorful clothes with evil intentions, greedily considering them beautiful, and thus obtained this sin.
Parrots with red lips, beaks, and feet are because in a past life they liked colorful clothes and red lips.
Women like to wear long skirts, and in their next life they fall into the bodies of pheasants with long tails. All are due to what they liked in the past, and now they obtain it as a result.

People and animals with many sores on their bodies are because in a past life they used wood and bamboo to pierce the mouths of living fish and animals, and in this life they obtain this sin as a result.
If people and animals see each other, some are happy and some are angry, because in a past life they were good to each other, and in this life when they see each other they are happy;
because in a past life they were incompatible, in this life when they see each other they are not happy.
Being a beast is an evil blessing. When one gets food, one is happy, which is an evil joy.
It means that the person, having done evil in a past life, was happy, and thus obtained this blessing.
Beasts cannot get delicious food for three reasons:
First, they do not practice;
Second, their good blessings are exhausted;
Third, their sins naturally lead them.
Beasts also desire form, sound, smell, taste, and touch. They also speak to each other, but they cannot speak like humans.
Women with beards come from sheep and chickens and ducks in the world, and therefore have beards.
Fish and turtles have no sound because in a past life they cut off people's speech.
Fish do not give birth immediately, but after seven days they give birth.
They are placed on dry grass and wood for forty or fifty years, and only then do they give birth when they get water.
The reason they have many offspring is that they do many evil things, and their sins are the same, so they are born together.
Those who are prone to anger, jealousy, stupidity, and lust, engaging in these four, fall into the category of monkeys;
Those who are not careful in their actions also fall into the category of monkeys.
People who enjoy performing as entertainers fall into the category of birds, insects, and monkeys in their next life.
Those who enjoy learning to kill and sacrifice fall into the category of sheep in their next life.
Why is this so?
They cut open people's scalps and flay them.
Perhaps in their past lives they enjoyed robbing people and taking away people's clothes, so they receive retribution.
Insects also, in their past lives, robbed people and took away people's clothes, causing them to shiver in the cold towards the fire.
Therefore, they first receive this retribution, spitting silk and freezing themselves, entering boiling water and fire to die.
The foolish and deluded enjoy killing, and in their next life they become pigs.
Those who frighten people become deer in their next life.ğŸ”½Those who greedily enjoy delicious food become flies in their next life.
Those who enjoy beating people become donkeys in their next life.
The reason for their long ears is that they enjoyed pulling people's ears.
Animals like to bite people's ears, or they may be former soldiers.
Why is it so?
When one soldier shouts, the other soldiers all make noise;
when one donkey bray, the other donkeys also bray.
Those who do not repay debts become oxen.
There are two reasons why oxen have split hooves:
first, they have debts;
second, they like to wear wooden clogs as a fashion.
There are two reasons why horses have complete hooves:
first, they have debts;
second, they like to wear wooden shoes as a fashion.
There were six people who were companions and all fell into hell, together in one cauldron, all wanting to speak of their original crimes:
One person said:
Sha, two people said:
Na, three people said:
Chi, four people said:
She, five people said:
Gu, six people said:
Dhara.
The Buddha saw this and smiled. MaudgalyÄyana asked the Buddha why he was smiling.
The Buddha said:

There were six people who were companions, together in a cauldron in hell, each wanting to speak for themselves, but the boiling water surged and they could not speak again, each saying a word and then sinking again.
The first person said 'sha', meaning: 'In the world, for six thousand million years, in hell for one day, when will it end?'
The second person said 'na', meaning: 'There is no end, and I do not know when I will be able to escape.'
The third person said 'chi', meaning: 'Alas! Alas! I should have lived to make a living, but I was unable to control my mind, and in the past I did not know when to stop.'
The fourth person said 'she', meaning: 'I made a living with sincerity, and I also made my wealth belong to others, and I suffer pain because of this.'
The fifth person said, Who can guarantee that after I escape from hell, I will not violate the precepts again and attain the bliss of the heavens?

The sixth person said, This matter was not originally planned, like driving a chariot that loses the main road, enters a wrong path, and breaks the chariot's spokes, regretting that there is nothing to do.

The Buddha spoke of the four gates. From the world up to the sixth heaven is the gate of death. From the seventh heaven up to the eighteenth heaven is the gate of emptiness. From the nineteenth heaven up to the twenty-third heaven is the gate of impermanence. From the twenty-fifth heaven up to the twenty-eighth heaven is the gate of leaving.
Leaving these four gates is the way out.
Extreme blessings do not exceed the twenty-eighth heaven, and extreme evil does not exceed the AvÄ«ci hell. The remaining calamities and sins all have degrees.
From one thing, there are the three poisons. From the three poisons, there are the three evil paths;
There will be no three evil paths, and all humans will attain the Way.
From AvÄ«ci, the great hell, up to the sixth heaven, they will form a single realm;
From the seventh heaven up to the nineteenth heaven, they will practice the four kinds of equanimity, and again form a single realm;
From the twenty-fifth heaven, practicing impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self, up to the twenty-eighth heaven, they will again form a single realm.

Not escaping the twenty-eight heavens, with the three poisons not yet exhausted, they will descend and become humans again, coming and going in the three realms. If they wish to seek liberation, they should extinguish thoughts.
From AvÄ«ci, the great hell, up to the sixth heaven, it is the realm of desire;
From the seventh heaven up to the nineteenth heaven, it is the realm of form;
From the twenty-fifth heaven up to the twenty-eighth heaven, it is the realm of non-form, without form, yet also with thoughts.
From AvÄ«ci hell up to the twenty-eighth heaven is the realm of birth and death;
Beyond the twenty-eighth heaven is the unconditioned realm.
Cutting off lust leads to the form realm;
Cutting off anger leads to the realm of no thought;
Cutting off delusion leads to the essential escape.
The three realms have three places:
First, from AvÄ«ci hell up to the sixth heaven, it is the place of lust;
Second, from the seventh heaven up to the nineteenth heaven, it is called the realm of form;
Third, excluding the fourth heaven up to the anÄgÄmin, from the twenty-fifth heaven up to the twenty-eighth heaven, it is called the realm of no form with no thought and also with thought.
These are the three places, falling into the cycle of birth and death and the realm of form.
It is like a fire's light, which can only be seen but cannot be grasped.
Being in the realm of lust and in the realm of joyful form, these are the three places.
From the hells, animal realm, and hungry ghost realm, lust and form should be cut off and one should aspire to the three liberations.
What is the essential path?
There are three bases:
There are roots of evil, roots of goodness, and roots of the Way.
Hell, animals, and hungry ghosts are the roots of evil;
From humans up to the sixth heaven, this is the root of goodness;
From the seventh heaven and above, the twelve gates are the root of the Way.
Those who have reached the twenty-eight heavens but have not attained liberation have three causes:
First, greed;
Second, delusion;
Third, intention.
Therefore, they cannot be liberated.
Having emerged from the twelve gates, one should wish to be without intention.
If the three poisons are not severed and one does not attain liberation, it is because they have not been exhausted.
Why is it the twenty-eight heavens?
In one's previous life in the world, because one was not greedy for the body and scattered the mind, one severed the seven external matters;
Above the sixth heaven, one receives blessings and severs the three internal matters.
Above the eighteenth heaven, from the twenty-first heaven, there are four places belonging to the anÄgÄmins.
Those who practice the ten wholesome deeds and are reborn in the first heaven or the sixth heaven do so because their goodness is more or less.
Those who practice the ten evil deeds and enter hell, or become animals or hungry ghosts, do so because their evil is more or less.
Practicing goodness can lead to evil, and practicing evil can lead to goodness. There is a little evil in goodness, and a little goodness in evil, so subtle it is hard to see.
But in goodness there is no little evil, and one will not fall into evil again;
in evil there is no little goodness, and one cannot escape.
The most evil is no worse than the AvÄ«ci Hell, and the most good is no better than the twenty-eight heavens. Because one is unaware of the subtle meaning, one cannot escape.

All who are reborn in the heavens and among humans do so by practicing the ten wholesome deeds. The reason celestials and humans are born through transformation is that when they were in the world, they did not focus on form, but were aware of the impurity of filth. From this they attain transformation.
If one has such thoughts, one will be reborn in a womb.
There are five causes and conditions for devas to attain rebirth through transformation:
First, not being intimate with women;
Second, the mind not arising;
Third, not wishing to be a child;
Fourth, enjoying sitting alone;
Fifth, not being attached to the world.
Not being greedy for the body, one can also attain rebirth through transformation.
When a person's life is about to end, they should hold their mind and contemplate the breath. The mind sometimes becomes attached to the breath.
From the first heaven upward, this mind contemplates the body as having thirty-two substances. It calculates:
Hair, body hair, teeth, bones, skin, flesh, and the five internal organs - these eleven things belong to earth;
Tears, mucus, saliva, pus, blood, fat, marrow, and urine - these seven things belong to water;
Warmth, heat, and digestion - these two things belong to fire;
There are twelve kinds of wind.
These thirty-two things all come from earth, water, fire, and wind.
What is earth?
When a person is born from the essence of grains, the grains are earth, the mind is the seed, the essence is water, and the two combine to produce the body.
Seeking one piece of clothing or one meal is called nourishing the qi to protect the host's body.
Because it originally did not exist, it will eventually perish and is impermanent.
If one attains the Way, one will know that the body is not the self, and that the body will not last long and will eventually die and decay.
The mind is the seed of a person, so one should guard the mind and be single-minded.

A foolish person cannot guard the soul and spirit, but only nourishes the four limbs. Deceived by the taste of form, they think the body is the self. Clinging to evil, everything arises from the body. Greedily pursuing food and drink for the taste, one falls into suffering and wanders in birth and death without escape.

Originally encountering evil, the soul and spirit leave in vain, heading towards the path of good and evil. When the body dies and falls to the ground, it decays day and night, and is also originally non-existent. It is only because of mental activity that it transforms and becomes a body. When the body dies, it all returns to earth. All things are also like this. They all pass away and are impermanent.
People do not consider themselves, but think of myriad things in many ways. None of them are for one's own sake. This is suffering.

When the body dies and is discarded, myriad things are also like this. They also perish and are already gone. They are reborn again and suffer again. Then they create good and evil actions, planting seeds and not knowing where they will go. This is non-self.
A practitioner of the Way should end this.
If one does not know the four kinds of impermanence, one will never attain the Way.
One should consider oneself and view all deaths and failures. Know that people and things are all empty, empty and non-existent. The mind then abides in stillness and attains the joy of practice.
Having attained practice, the mind is then at ease.
Not leaving the five, the mind is one. This is the Way.

One should contemplate one's own body and know that it is non-existent, and then one can attain the cessation of body and mind. The cessation of body and mind also includes the cessation of feelings, mind, and dharmas.
Cessation refers to three things: the cessation of feelings, the cessation of feelings and mind, and the cessation of four things:
The cessation of greed, the cessation of mind, and the cessation of three things internally;
The cessation of thoughts, the cessation of mental activities, and the cessation of consciousness are the cessation of external dharmas.
These are the four foundations of mindfulness.
Cessation leads to guarding, and guarding leads to contemplation.
Therefore, the sutra says:
The practice of both cessation and contemplation leads to the realization of the Four Noble Truths.
Therefore, the Buddha said:
Sitting alone in meditation, contemplating one's own mind, means contemplating the cessation of form, feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness.

The cessation of one's own mind means the cessation of external thoughts, always practicing as if there were a path, seeing the path as if it were present, and thus seeing for oneself through sitting practice.
The sutra says:
Bhiká¹£us, if you can thus cease internally and guard the cessation,
This mind should first contemplate, think of cessation, and wait for the mind itself to guard the mind.
The mind does not leave the body, and the practitioner waits outside, referring to myriad things;
Thoughts are within, referring to thoughts.
Consciousness desires to extinguish thoughts, always thinking that things are impermanent and decaying, all not belonging to me, and I am also not belonging to things.
Quickly think of death, holding what to take when dying?
Holding goodness, holding the single mind, holding recitation of the sÅ«tras, and delighting in them.
The Buddha said:
This is your possession to take, the rest are all not belonging to me.

The mind should recognize and think of the love and affection that will eventually separate, each dissolving and decaying, thinking of it only confuses the mind, following one's faults, there must be a return to the body, guarding purity, and heading towards the path of nirvana.
The Buddha goes from the single mind to the nine paths, thinking that the four colors will all be extinguished.
Referring to a person dying for four or five days, about to rot and decay, the color turns to pure blue;
On the fifth and sixth days, pus and blood flow from the mouth, nose, ears, and eyes, bright red;
Later, the flesh decays, worms grow in the intestines and stomach, and they eat their own flesh. The skin dissolves, the bones turn white,
After a long time, they turn black and become ash and soil.
Earth, water, fire, wind, and space are all not what I possess!

Since beginningless time, you have also been a person's wife, husband, or servant, and have also been a livestock such as a cow, horse, or insect, suffering heavy burdens and debts, and have been slaughtered and cut up by people.

Now as a person, you again take people as your wife, husband, or servant, and also take livestock such as cows, horses, or insects, slaughtering, cutting up, stabbing, and chopping at will. When the body dies, you will all have to undergo this again.
Practitioner!

Have you ever seen a person die, their breath cease, and they become unconscious? The body becomes stiff and straight, then stinks and decays, becoming disgusting. Contemplate this and you will fear it, not wanting to see it.
Why is it not feared?
It causes people to ascend to heaven and attain the path of nirvana.
Because the Buddha knows that the nine realms are all empty and nonexistent, he returns to the one mind.

The practitioner quickly extinguishes thoughts, attends to nothing else, and immediately reaches the profound and solid practice of restraint, deeply abiding in the seen, and not using what is not present, therefore not seeing.
The mind desires, and thoughts of impermanence and decay arise. One should contemplate the opposite of lust, the equality of anger, and the delusion of the mind.

The fundamental practice is not constant, and there is peace without action. People do not know impermanence, and in the end they do not abandon desire, nor do they leave the path of the three lower realms.
All that exists in the world is like a dream. In a dream, one eats and sees what is good, but upon waking, it is gone.
All that exists in the world is like this - birth leads to death, formation leads to destruction, and everything eventually returns to emptiness. What is there to desire?
People who have wives, children, and property are also like this.
Why is it so?
When people engage in business and obtain money and profit, if their family members gather and rejoice,
it is like a flock of birds gathering, all of which are impermanent. Once they part, they will never be seen again;
even if they are permanent, there are myriad worries and fears. The mind is in the midst of birth and death, accumulating sins day by day.
A wise person restrains themselves, has few desires, and seeks only one garment and one meal;
they practice from a state of concentration, do not seek a place to rest, always return to guard the purity of the body, and cut off thoughts and contemplate emptiness.
Question:
From what does the practice of guarding the mind originate?
It is said:
Heaven and earth have their natures, and humans come down from the fifteenth heaven above, with a lifespan without premature death.
They are pulled out of the five paths of birth and death, which arise from the six decaying faculties.
A person's mind and thoughts are originally good, without greed, love, pain, itching, thoughts, birth and death, and consciousness. They are deceived by the eyes, ears, nose, and mouth.

First, the eyes see forms, the ears hear sounds, the nose knows smells, the mouth knows tastes, and the mind thinks. By doing these ten things, the five aggregates are formed. The mind is consciousness, which together form the six sense faculties. Based on this, good and bad actions are created and seeds are formed. From this, old age, sickness, and death arise.

Seeking the Way in the five realms, wishing to end birth and death, one guards one's own mind, stopping the eyes from forms, the ears from sounds, the nose from smells, the mouth from tastes, and the body from pleasures. Stopping the six sense faculties, observing the destruction of the mind, sitting in meditation to extinguish thoughts.
Those who attain the Way through consciousness completely extinguish the five aggregates.
Knowing the original non-existence, one then contemplates emptiness and directly heads towards the gate of nirvana.
For those who guard the mind, the mind is the master of consciousness and action. Therefore, the six sense faculties are the cause of calamity, and the five realms are the root of action.
A practitioner of the Way contemplates deeply, guarding the four intentions, wishing to stop and be free from evil. He is aware of the thoughts and knows which path they run towards.
If a person wishes to extinguish thoughts, consciousness, and ideas, they should practice everything and not cut off the ten things of the body.
The three things of body, speech, and mind are determined, and the five aggregates and six sense bases are then correct.
The three concentrations are:
Speech without knowledge is the concentration of speech, the body without knowledge is the concentration of the body, and the mind without thoughts is the concentration of the mind.
The mind has four illnesses. Those with much delusion are said to have much in the five aggregates.
When the five aggregates are much, the mind runs and cannot be practiced.
When it cannot be practiced, it becomes angry and lustful thoughts arise. Unable to control it, one falls into delusion.
Therefore, in practicing the Way, one must cut off the five aggregates. Cutting off the five aggregates, pain, itching, and much desire are it.
The teacher said:
The body does not wish to practice because of much fatigue;
The mind does not wish to practice because it does not wish to think of the suffering, emptiness, and decay of death.
He asked:
What is the basis for birth?
The teacher said:
It is said that non-doubt is the fundamental root.
What is the direction?
What is the opposite?
What is the practice?
The master said:
Not turning the mind is the direction, not turning thoughts is the opposite, pleasing the mind is the practice.
He asked:
What kind of field is it?
Who is called the farmer?
You have a mind, but the farmer does not know if you have no mind.
The farmer is not aware, are you aware with a mind or not aware with no mind?
It can be said that the mind is aware.
The taste of lust is also the mind.
Why is it so?
Because it is not aware of what is near.
Leaving the household life has no field, this is how it is.
He asked:
Is there a mind in the Buddha's hometown or not?

It is like this. Originally there is no body or mind, but one creates this attainment by oneself. It is like the five kinds of seeds, which also do not grow without seeds. The birth of a person is also originally without seeds.
It is like kindling a fire, the flames come out and become embers;
When the firewood is gone, it stops.
People themselves calculate the body as not the body, and myriad things also cease.
The opponent said:
Originally there is no intention, so what is the purpose of guarding?
The master said:
Because of originally being non-existent, it can be guarded;
Destroying what originally exists cannot be guarded.
The master said:
The Way has four essentials:
First, the gate of holding the multitude;
Second, knowing that the body is not the body, then destroying the body and not loving it again, this is leaving the human realm and entering the gate of the sixth heaven;

Third, knowing that the mind of impermanence no longer turns towards [samsara], this is leaving through the gate of the eighteenth heaven. Fourth, like extinguishing emptiness in emptiness, this is leaving through the gate of the twenty-eighth heaven, because extinguishing emptiness then falls into the Way.
The sutra says:
Those who realize the Way and leave are those who realize suffering, emptiness, non-self, and impermanence.
Leaving means leaving through the four essential realms and attaining the seven heavens above the first dhyana, where there is only a body and a shadow.
Why is this?
Because practicing the Way destroys the body.
Contemplating the body, the head, hair, and brain, one thinks that the hair originally came from nowhere, was created and transformed, and will all rot and fall away;
the brain is like congealed rice gruel, all of which will become foul and spoil;
the eyes are just holes, and the water will all flow out and become empty;
the ears are just holes, all filled with earwax and leaking water;
the nose and mouth are filled with saliva and mucus, all of which will flow out, scatter, and dissolve;

The tongue, throat, lungs, liver, and heart, the bad blood in the heart;ğŸ”½The gall bladder, diaphragm, spleen attached to the stomach, kidneys attached to the spine, the stomach contains flavors and digests food;
The large intestine has feces, the small intestine has holes and urine, the small intestine all should swell and rot;
The intestines, stomach, feces and urine splash each other, the foul place is disgusting;
Below there is the buttocks meat and blood, the two shins, the two feet, the muscles and flesh are exhausted, the sinews and veins are destroyed;
The bones are locked, the joints are disjointed and fall apart;

The shins are solid and white, the thigh bones are like cart wheels, the buttocks bones are connected to the spine, the shoulder bones are connected to the elbows, arms, and hands, the leather also decays, the joints are disjointed and fall apart;
The neck bones are connected to the skull, the blood and flesh are exhausted, and they turn into ash and soil again.
All wriggling creatures exhale without retribution, and then pass away, the body becomes straight and does not move again.
When the fire leaves the body, it becomes cold. When the wind leaves, the breath ceases. The juices flow out from the nine orifices and become water, and the lack of food becomes earth.

In three or four days, the color turns blue and black. Pus and blood flow out from the mouth, nose, ears, eyes, and the nine orifices. The raw flesh, bones, and muscles decay, and the intestines, stomach, five viscera, and limbs all turn back into ash and soil.
View all things in this way, and one's own body is also like this, all extinguished and empty.
Know the exhalation and inhalation of breath to be empty, and one can then approach the Way.
